Award.AbstractNarration: This award is made as part of the FY 2012 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. These fellowships support a research and training plan at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines. The title of the research fellowship awarded to Owen G. Gwilliam is "Construction and mathematical applications of quantum field theories." The host institution for the fellowship is University of California, Berkeley, and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Nicolai Reshetikhin.

Performance_Institution.Name: University of California, Berkeley, Department of Mathematics

POR.DRECONTENT:
Thanks to the Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowship that I received in 2012, I have had the opportunity to undertake research and pursue collaborations that would have been, at minimum, much more difficult with an ordinary postdoctoral position. Before elaborating on the research itself, let me describe briefly what I did over the  three years of this Fellowship.


Here is the output of the research:

  • the completion of two 300-page research monographs (the first was published in December 2016) and
  • five papers (~260 pages) from four separate collaborations.

(All are freely available on my website, and the papers are also available at arXiv.org.) Most of the substantive work on these projects was completed during the periods when I did not teach, time provided expressly by the Fellowship. 


That flexible time also made it possible for me to organize several conferences and workshops at premier institutions for my research area, such as the Simons Center for Geometry and Physics, the Banff International Research Station, and the Oberwolfach Mathematics Research Institute. These events not only gave me the chance to meet and interact with many researchers in mathematics and physics, but directly led to new collaborations (for others as well as for me).


The funds for travel and the teaching-free time allowed me to give 14 talks and two 3-hour lecture series. I was also able to host collaborators who lacked their own funds.

Let me emphasize my deep gratitude for the flexibility provided by the Fellowship, as my wife and I grappled with being new parents during a postdoctoral position (for me) and medical residency (for my wife). This Fellowship was also divided between the University of California, Berkeley (Fall 2012-Summer 2014) and Max Planck Institute for Mathematics in Bonn, Germany (Fall 2014-Summer 2015). It was a godsend that the Fellowship could be transferred, as my wife's work took her (and my son) to Germany.

So, finally, what was the research that this Fellowship made possible? Let me attempt a very brief and non-technical account. 

Since the inception of modern science, theoretical physics and mathematics have engaged in a vigorous dialogue, sharing problems and techniques. Indeed, a sizable portion of mathematics was developed in direct response to the needs of physics, such as calculus and the theory of differential equations. There is often a time lag between the subjects: physicists blithely worked with those tools although mathematicians would say that a satisfactory theory of calculus (to mathematicians!) only appeared several centuries after these techniques first appeared. In the twentieth century, physicists developed an incredibly successful collection of ideas and algorithms known as quantum field theory (QFT), used to predict the behavior both of subatomic particles as well as of metals, semiconductors, and superconductors. It is safe to say that, although mathematicians have put immense effort into understanding QFT, we do not yet have a comprehensive, satisfactory theory. My research is part of current efforts in that direction. More specifically, my research fits into those current efforts that apply to physics some a priori purely theoretical advances in twentieth (and twenty-first) century mathematics, notably homological algebra and category theory.
